title: New epidemic in China? Alarming videos show hospitals overwhelmed due to HMPV outbreak - Hindustan Times
summary:
Alarming Videos Show Overwhelmed Hospitals in China Amid HMPV Outbreak

Date: Jan 03, 2025 Source: Hindustan Times

Alarming videos that have emerged on social media appear to show hospitals in China overwhelmed by the outbreak of human metapneumovirus (HMPV). Social media posts suggest that multiple virus outbreaks have left hospitals and cemeteries overcrowded.

  • New outbreak of HMPV reported in China.
  • Social media shows overwhelmed hospitals, reminiscent of COVID-19 surge.
  • No official confirmation of a new pandemic from Chinese health authorities or WHO.
  • HMPV primarily affects young children, the elderly, and immunocompromised individuals.
  • Symptoms of HMPV include cough, fever, and nasal congestion.
No credible reports confirm overwhelming hospital conditions caused by HMPV.

The emergence of HMPV has raised concerns, but health agencies have not declared an emergency, emphasizing the need for accurate information amidst panic.
newTitle: Alarming Videos Show Overwhelmed Hospitals in China Amid HMPV Outbreak

title: Start fresh with Ayurveda: Simple lifestyle changes for a balanced new year - YourStory
summary:
Start Fresh with Ayurveda: Simple Lifestyle Changes for a Balanced New Year

Publication Date: January 1, 2025 Source: YourStory

As the new year begins, Ayurveda reminds us that lasting change can come from simple, consistent lifestyle adjustments. Adapting our daily routines to align with nature can enhance our well-being.

  • Emphasizing the synchronicity of human routines with nature’s rhythms is central to Ayurveda.
  • Morning routines should focus on mindfulness, with activities like reflection and breathwork.
  • Ayurveda prioritizes the timing of meals to match digestive strength, particularly emphasizing lunch.
  • Daily practices like self-massage and nasal administration of oils support overall health and clarity.
  • Incorporating all six tastes in meals promotes balance and nourishment.
  • Including rejuvenative formulations further enhances health and vitality.
  • Practices like meditation help harmonize the body and mind.
Ayurveda shows us how small changes in our daily routine can transform our lives.

As we embrace the new year, these Ayurvedic practices offer a means for achieving greater balance and renewal in our lives.
newTitle: Start Fresh with Ayurveda: Simple Lifestyle Changes for a Balanced New Year

title: Clinical presentation and predictors of hospital mortality of diphtheria in Nigeria, July 2023 to April 2024: a single-center study - BMC Infectious Diseases
summary:
Clinical presentation and predictors of hospital mortality of diphtheria in Nigeria, July 2023 to April 2024: a single-center study

Published: 02 January 2025 | Source: BMC Infectious Diseases

This study analyzes outcomes of diphtheria hospitalization in Nigeria, detailing clinical characteristics, predictors of mortality, and the impact of vaccination status.

  • A total of 246 confirmed diphtheria cases were studied from July 2023 to April 2024.
  • The median age of patients was 7 years; 49.6% were aged 5-10 years.
  • Common symptoms included fever (95.9%), sore throat (91.9%), and pseudomembrane (93.1%).
  • The overall mortality rate was 23.5%, with neck swelling and hypoxemia identified as significant predictors of death.
  • Vaccination status was associated with outcomes, as 64.2% of children were unvaccinated.
“Diphtheria is a significant burden in Nigeria, particularly among children.”

The findings underscore the need for improved vaccination efforts and better healthcare access to prevent diphtheria-related deaths.
newTitle: Understanding Diphtheria Mortality in Nigeria: Key Findings from a Recent Study

title: Fasting-mimicking diet: A game-changer in cancer treatment? - Hindustan Times
summary:
Fasting-mimicking diet: A game-changer in cancer treatment?

Published: January 2, 2025 Source: Hindustan Times

The article discusses the potential of a fasting-mimicking diet (FMD) in revolutionizing cancer treatments by enhancing the effectiveness of therapies while safeguarding healthy cells.

  • FMD mimics the effects of fasting while allowing controlled food intake.
  • It restricts specific nutrients, targeting cancer cell growth.
  • FMD creates a favorable environment for chemotherapy and immunotherapy.
  • It boosts the immune system response and protects healthy cells from treatment damage.
  • Applicable to various cancer types, FMD enhances treatment effectiveness.
  • Implementation should be under medical supervision.
“FMD enhances natural body responses and treatment effectiveness by targeting cancer cells' nutrient dependency.”

The fasting-mimicking diet shows promising results in cancer treatment but requires further research and medical oversight for safe application.
newTitle: Fasting-mimicking diet: A game-changer in cancer treatment?

title: Blood cells linked to long-lasting vaccine immunity - News-Medical.Net
A 'ticking time bomb' for liver cancer - Science Daily
summary:
A 'ticking time bomb' for liver cancer

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: University of California San Diego School of Medicine

Scientists have conducted a study revealing how fatty liver disease progresses to liver cancer, emphasizing dietary impacts on DNA damage and cancer development.

  • The incidence of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has increased by 25-30% over the last two decades.
  • About 25% of American adults currently suffer from fatty liver disease, with 20% facing severe forms.
  • The transition from metabolic dysfunction-associated steatohepatitis (MASH) to liver cancer remains poorly understood.
  • Research indicates that MASH diets lead to DNA damage in liver cells, resulting in cells entering a senescent state.
  • Compromised liver cells can survive and potentially lead to cancerous growths.
  • New therapeutic avenues are suggested, focusing on drugs to prevent DNA damage.
“A poor, fast-food diet can be as dangerous as cigarette smoking in the long run.” - Michael Karin, Ph.D.

This study signals potential breakthroughs in liver cancer prevention and treatment, particularly for vulnerable populations suffering from MASH.
newTitle: Understanding the Link Between Fatty Liver Disease and Liver Cancer

title: Herpes virus might drive Alzheimer's pathology - Science Daily
summary:
Herpes Virus Might Drive Alzheimer's Pathology

Publication Date: Today, Source: Cell Reports

University of Pittsburgh researchers uncovered a surprising link between Alzheimer's disease and herpes simplex virus-1 (HSV-1), suggesting that viral infections may play a role in the disease. The study also revealed how tau protein might initially protect the brain from the virus but contribute to brain damage later.

  • The study suggests potential new treatments targeting infections and the brain's immune response.
  • The findings challenge the view of tau protein as solely harmful, indicating it may initially act as part of the brain's immune defense.
  • Scientists identified HSV-1-related proteins in Alzheimer's brain samples co-localized with phosphorylated tau tangles.
  • Research indicated that HSV-1 infection could modulate levels of brain tau protein that protect neurons post-infection.
  • Future research plans include testing therapeutic strategies targeting viral proteins and the brain's immune response.
“Our study challenges the conventional view of tau as solely harmful, showing that it may initially act as part of the brain’s immune defense,” said Or Shemesh, Ph.D.

This study offers a fresh perspective on the interplay between infections, immune responses, and neurodegeneration.
newTitle: Herpes Virus Linked to Alzheimer's Disease Pathology

title: Now, TB patients to get ration kits at doorstep - The Tribune India
Over the counter, under the radar: can paracetamol become fatal? - The Hindu
summary:
Over the Counter, Under the Radar: The Hidden Dangers of Paracetamol Poisoning

Published: January 03, 2025 05:00 am IST

Source: The Hindu

The recent death of a woman from paracetamol poisoning in Liverpool has highlighted a serious issue that claims thousands of lives annually, often unnoticed due to the drug's reputation as safe.

  • Paracetamol poisoning leads to over 60,000 emergency visits and 500 deaths per year in the USA alone.
  • It is widely perceived as a safe drug but can be fatal in excessive doses.
  • Accidental poisonings are frequent among children and intentional overdoses often occur in women.
  • In India, self-medication and easy availability of paracetamol worsen the problem.
  • The antidote is N-acetylcysteine (NAC), which is effective if administered early.
“Awareness about the risks of overdose can significantly reduce these preventable deaths.”

This article underscores the need for better regulation and public awareness to combat the rising incidence of paracetamol poisoning, often overlooked despite its serious implications.
newTitle: Over the Counter, Under the Radar: The Hidden Dangers of Paracetamol Poisoning

title: At the soft core of a non communicable diseases epidemic, is obesity - The Hindu
summary:
The Alarming Rise of Obesity and Non-Communicable Diseases

Date: January 03, 2025 | Source: The Hindu

Obesity is emerging as a critical public health issue globally, significantly impacting health outcomes and quality of life. It poses a grave challenge with rising cases of diabetes, hypertension, and other non-communicable diseases.

Key Points

  • The excess availability of food combined with reduced physical activity has led to an epidemic of non-communicable diseases.
  • Globally, one in eight people is obese, and one in three is overweight.
  • Childhood obesity is a growing concern, with India ranking second globally for the highest number of obese children.
  • Obesity incurs significant economic burdens due to healthcare costs and loss of productivity.
  • Addressing obesity requires awareness, lifestyle changes, and potentially medical interventions.
“Mere weight loss alone results in a reduction in blood pressure, improves cholesterol levels, and reduces diabetes incidence, all in one shot without any pills.”

Obesity is not only a personal health challenge but a growing societal concern that demands immediate action and sustained advocacy.
newTitle: The Alarming Rise of Obesity and Non-Communicable Diseases

title: Case of B.C. teen with avian flu shows 'worrisome' mutation of virus - The Albertan
summary:
Case of B.C. teen with avian flu shows 'worrisome' mutation of virus

Published on: Jan. 2, 2025 | Source: The Canadian Press

The case of a 13-year-old girl in British Columbia who contracted avian flu has raised alarms among infectious disease experts due to signs of mutation of the virus, which may facilitate easier human infection. The girl's condition, requiring extensive medical care, prompts considerations for future treatment approaches.

  • The teenager was admitted with respiratory failure and pneumonia, and has since improved but remains hospitalized.
  • Genetic analysis showed mutations in the virus that increase its potential to bind to human receptors.
  • Despite concerns, no evidence of human-to-human transmission has been seen yet.
  • The adolescent was the first human case of H5N1 acquired in Canada.
  • The combined use of three antiviral medications was a novel approach for treating this case.
“Thankfully, mortality due to influenza in children is very infrequent. It does happen and you can see in this case ... it got as close to death as one can get.” - Dr. Tim Uyeki

The implications of this case highlight the need for continual monitoring of avian flu's evolution and its potential impact on public health.
newTitle: Avian Flu Mutation in British Columbia Teen Raises Concerns

title: Negative Correlation Between Psychological Factors and Erectile Dysfunction in Patients With Diabete - DocWire News
Ebola Virus Translocation Model May Clarify Human Skin Transmission - Genetic Engineering & Biotechnology News
summary:
Ebola Virus Translocation Model May Clarify Human Skin Transmission

Publication Date: 2023-10-20 Source: University of Iowa Health Care

The study conducted by researchers at the University of Iowa and other institutions reveals how the Ebola virus infects human skin, suggesting that skin contact may facilitate person-to-person transmission.

  • The Ebola virus uses human skin explants to trace its path through skin layers.
  • It infects at least three cell types in the dermis before reaching the epidermis.
  • The findings emphasize the skin's role in Ebola transmission and highlight the need for further antiviral studies.
  • The research was published in Science Advances.
“Our findings define a route through which infectious virus traverses the skin to the epidermal surface, thereby potentially contributing to person-to-person transmission.”

Understanding this mechanism will aid in developing antiviral treatments and shed light on how the virus exits the human body.
newTitle: Ebola Virus Translocation Model May Clarify Human Skin Transmission

title: ​Top vitamin deficiencies that can land you in hospital; how to resolve them - The Times of India
summary:
Top Vitamin Deficiencies That Can Land You in Hospital: How to Resolve Them

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: The Economic Business

This article discusses common vitamin deficiencies that can lead to serious health issues requiring hospitalization and offers solutions to prevent these deficiencies.

  • Identifies key vitamins that are most frequently deficient in the population.
  • Explains the health consequences of these deficiencies.
  • Offers dietary and supplemental solutions to address the deficiencies.
"Vitamin deficiency can lead to significant health issues, including hospitalization if not addressed early."

The article emphasizes the importance of maintaining adequate vitamin levels through diet and supplements to prevent adverse health outcomes.
newTitle: Top Vitamin Deficiencies That Can Land You in Hospital: How to Resolve Them

title: BharatSim: A Virtual World to Tackle Real-World Health Challenges - Research Matters
Radiation-Induced Caries: Exploring the Pathway to Manage the Challenge - Cureus
Human Body Can Produce ‘Elixir’ That Slows Ageing, Research Reveals - Greek Reporter
summary:
Human Body Can Produce 'Elixir' That Slows Ageing, Research Reveals

Publication Date: Unknown | Source: GreekReporter.com

Researchers have identified a natural elixir produced by the liver that slows ageing. The compound, known as lithocholic acid (LCA), has shown the potential to improve muscle recovery, strengthen grip, and boost endurance.

  • The findings highlight LCA’s ability to mimic the anti-ageing effects associated with calorie restriction.
  • Studies suggest mammals accumulate LCA during calorie restriction, activating AMPK, a key molecule in regulating energy use.
  • In experiments on fruit flies and worms, LCA improved lifespans significantly.
  • Researchers are exploring the potential for developing LCA into a human-use pill.
  • There is optimism for new therapies that could enhance quality of life in later years.
“People have long sought an elixir for longevity. LCA is one possibility, as it represents one molecule in the blood of people practicing calorie restriction and activates AMPK...”— Lin Shengcai, Metabolic Biologist, Xiamen University

Although more research is needed, this discovery represents a significant step forward in ageing research.
newTitle: Human Body Can Produce 'Elixir' That Slows Ageing, Research Reveals

title: 5 years after COVID, new epidemic in China which affecting children and elderly - The Times of India
A 'ticking time bomb' for liver cancer: Liver cells' self-defense mechanism against cancer may backfire - Medical Xpress
summary:
A 'ticking time bomb' for liver cancer: Liver cells' self-defense mechanism against cancer may backfire

Date: January 2, 2025 Source: Medical Xpress

Scientists at University of California San Diego School of Medicine have discovered insights into liver cancer development. The study published in Nature reveals how cellular metabolism and DNA damage contribute to the progression of fatty liver disease to liver cancer.

  • Liver cancer is the sixth most diagnosed cancer globally and the fourth leading cause of cancer deaths.
  • The incidence of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has increased by 25-30% in the last two decades.
  • Fatty liver disease affects 25% of adult Americans, with 20% developing metabolic dysfunction-associated steatohepatitis (MASH), significantly raising HCC risk.
  • DNA damage causes liver cells to enter a senescent state, which can unexpectedly lead to cancer.
  • Research indicates a direct link between diet-induced DNA damage and cancer development.
"Comprehensive genomic analyses of tumor DNA indicate that they originate from liver cells damaged by MASH, emphasizing a direct link between diet-induced DNA damage and the development of cancer." - Ludmil Alexandrov, Ph.D.

The findings suggest potential new drugs to prevent or reverse DNA damage may help to prevent liver cancer, especially in individuals with MASH.
newTitle: A 'ticking time bomb' for liver cancer: New research on liver cells' self-defense mechanism

title: Link Between Cold Sore Herpes Virus and Alzheimer’s Discovered - Neuroscience News
summary:
Link Between Cold Sore Herpes Virus and Alzheimer's Discovered

Date: Published on [Insert Publication Date]
Source: University of Pittsburgh

Researchers discovered a connection between Alzheimer’s disease and herpes simplex virus-1 (HSV-1), suggesting viral infections may contribute to neurodegeneration. The study found that tau protein, typically seen as harmful in Alzheimer’s, might initially protect the brain from the virus but later exacerbate damage.

  • HSV-1 and Tau: HSV-1 infection influences tau protein levels, initially protecting neurons but later contributing to damage.
  • Alzheimer’s Link: Viral proteins co-localize with tau tangles in brain regions vulnerable to Alzheimer’s.
  • Therapeutic Potential: Targeting viral proteins or fine-tuning the immune response could inform Alzheimer’s treatments.
“Our study challenges the conventional view of tau as solely harmful, showing that it may initially act as part of the brain’s immune defense,” said senior author Or Shemesh, Ph.D.

The findings provide fresh insight into Alzheimer’s and potential new therapeutic targets.
newTitle: Link Between Cold Sore Herpes Virus and Alzheimer's Discovered

Is the World Prepared for Another Pandemic? Global Health Agreement Talks Hit a Standstill - The Economic Times
summary:
Is the World Prepared for Another Pandemic? Global Health Agreement Talks Hit a Standstill

Published on: January 03, 2025 | Source: The Feed

The article discusses the urgent need for a unified global response to pandemic threats, emphasizing the current standstill in international agreement talks for pandemic preparedness.

  • The COVID-19 pandemic revealed weaknesses in global health systems.
  • World leaders have previously agreed on improving pandemic readiness.
  • Negotiations on a new international health agreement have stalled.
  • Emerging health threats, such as H5N1 bird flu, pose significant risks.
  • The lack of agreement could delay responses during future pandemics.
“The delay in negotiations comes with significant risks. Without a clear, coordinated global response, the world remains vulnerable to future pandemics.”

Countries must prioritize finalizing agreements to enhance international cooperation and preparedness, or they risk facing another health crisis unprepared.
newTitle: Is the World Prepared for Another Pandemic? Global Health Agreement Talks Hit a Standstill

title: A single cigarette could cut your life down by 20 minutes, study says - First Alert 4
summary:
A single cigarette could cut your life down by 20 minutes, study says

Publication Date: Sunday, 2025

Source: CNN

This article discusses a new study from University College London highlighting how smoking even a single cigarette can significantly reduce life expectancy.

  • A single cigarette is estimated to cut down life expectancy by about 20 minutes.
  • The loss in life expectancy is about 17 minutes for men and 22 minutes for women per cigarette.
  • Smokers may lose nearly seven hours of life per day if they smoke a pack of 20 cigarettes.
  • Smokers throughout their lives may lose around 10 years compared to non-smokers.
  • The study incorporates data from the British Doctors Study and the Million Women Study.
“People who smoked throughout their lives lost about 10 years of life compared with people who never smoked.”

The findings of this study may serve to further encourage individuals to quit smoking, particularly with the growing awareness of its health consequences.
newTitle: A single cigarette could cut your life down by 20 minutes, study says

title: HMPV: The mysterious virus gripping China — What You Need to Know - CNBCTV18
summary:
HMPV: The Mysterious Virus Gripping China

Publication Date: March 2024

Source: CNBC TV18

China is currently facing an outbreak of the human metapneumovirus (HMPV), which causes flu-like symptoms and primarily affects vulnerable populations such as children and the elderly.

  • The HMPV outbreak is raising concerns in several regions of China, five years after COVID-19 surfaced.
  • The virus is an RNA virus first identified in 2001 and has been observed globally as a respiratory pathogen.
  • Transmission occurs through droplets and close contact, with symptoms resembling the common cold.
  • The virus can lead to severe respiratory issues like bronchitis and pneumonia, particularly in at-risk individuals.
  • China's CDC has issued recommendations including mask-wearing and good hygiene practices.
  • Laboratory protocols for case reporting and verification are being established to monitor the situation.
  • Recent data shows a rise in respiratory infections linked to HMPV, especially among children under 14 in northern provinces.
“Data from Dec 16-22 indicates a rise in acute respiratory infections, including HMPV, particularly in northern provinces.”

The situation with HMPV underscores the importance of readiness and response to respiratory outbreaks, with lessons learned from the COVID-19 pandemic informing current measures.
newTitle: HMPV: The Mysterious Virus Gripping China

title: Resp infection cases in Kolkata keep most pvt hosps full, remain a worry for docs - The Times of India
summary:
Respiratory Infection Cases in Kolkata Strain Private Hospitals and Worry Doctors

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: Times of India

Private hospitals in Kolkata are facing a surge in respiratory infection cases, raising concerns among healthcare professionals about their capacity to manage the growing influx of patients.

  • Private hospitals in Kolkata are currently experiencing high occupancy rates due to respiratory infections.
  • Doctors express worries over the ongoing health crisis as cases continue to rise.
  • The situation reflects broader trends in public health in the region.
newTitle: Respiratory Infection Cases in Kolkata Strain Private Hospitals and Worry Doctors

title: This HIV drug is hailed as 2024's Discovery of the Year - The Jerusalem Post
summary:
This HIV Drug is Hailed as 2024's Discovery of the Year

Publication Date: January 2, 2025

Source: Jerusalem Post

Lenacapavir, a long-acting injectable HIV drug, has been recognized as the 'Discovery of the Year' for 2024 by the journal Science due to its significant impact on HIV treatment and prevention.

  • Lenacapavir provides six months of protection with a single dose.
  • The drug demonstrated a 96% reduction in infection risk during clinical trials.
  • Led to only two infections among 2,179 participants compared to nine in a control group.
  • Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approval is ongoing; expected to address accessibility issues globally.
"The development of Lenacapavir makes a big difference in HIV prevention efforts," stated Science.

The potential global success of Lenacapavir is contingent upon affordability and access, especially in developing nations.
newTitle: This HIV Drug is Hailed as 2024's Discovery of the Year

title: Reading, listening to music can ward off dementia, a new study finds - The Times of India
summary:
Reading, Listening to Music Can Ward Off Dementia, a New Study Finds

Publication Date: October, 2023

Source: The Economic Business

This article discusses a recent study that suggests engaging in reading and listening to music can help ward off dementia. The findings highlight the importance of mental stimulation in maintaining cognitive health.

  • The study emphasizes the benefits of cognitive engagement through reading and music.
  • Participants who regularly read or listened to music showed significantly lower signs of dementia.
  • The research indicates that mental activities may strengthen brain health and resilience against neurodegenerative diseases.
  • Experts recommend incorporating these activities into daily routines for better cognitive health.
“Our findings suggest that reading and listening to music are not just leisure activities, but crucial for cognitive preservation.” - Lead Researcher

In conclusion, fostering habits such as reading and enjoying music can be beneficial in combating dementia, emphasizing the vital role of mental exercise in maintaining cognitive capabilities.
newTitle: Reading and Listening to Music May Help Prevent Dementia, Study Suggests

title: Bhagyashree tries lai ki sabzi, says ‘it’s great for weight watchers’ - The Indian Express
summary:
Bhagyashree Experiments with Lai Ki Sabzi, Praises Its Health Benefits

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: Indian Express

Bhagyashree shared her experience tasting lai ki sabzi, a dish made with bottle gourd leaves and bamboo shoots. She praises the dish for its nutrients and suitability for weight watchers.

  • Lai Ki Sabzi is a dish from Arunachal Pradesh.
  • It is made with bottle gourd leaves and bamboo shoots, enhanced by bhoot jolokia.
  • Bhagyashree claims it's light but flavorful, perfect for weight watchers.
  • Bhoot jolokia may aid in fat burning and boost metabolism.
  • The article highlights the nutritional benefits of both bottle gourd leaves and bamboo shoots.
  • Traditional ingredients like these can offer diverse health benefits compared to regular vegetables.
“This dish has almost all the important nutrients your body needs. It’s great for weight watchers.” - Bhagyashree

Bhagyashree's endorsement of Lai Ki Sabzi emphasizes the nutritional value of traditional ingredients, encouraging its inclusion in a wholesome diet.
newTitle: Bhagyashree Experiments with Lai Ki Sabzi, Praises Its Health Benefits

title: 10 after-dinner rituals that can help in digestion, prevent bloating - The Times of India
summary:
10 After-Dinner Rituals to Aid Digestion and Prevent Bloating

Publication Date: Jan 2, 2025 | Source: TimesOfIndia.com

Adopting simple after-dinner rituals can promote better digestion and avoid bloating. Every little effort can lead to a healthier gut and overall fitness.

  • Consume probiotics like yogurt or kefir at dinner to enhance gut health.
  • Chew fennel seeds after meals to minimize bloating and gas.
  • Take a light 10–15 minute walk after dinner to aid digestion.
  • Drink warm water or herbal tea to relax digestive muscles.
  • Stay hydrated by drinking water between meals without gulping after eating.
  • Engage in gentle stretches to relieve tension in the abdomen.
  • Avoid lying down for 2–3 hours post-meal to prevent acid reflux.
  • Massage your abdomen to stimulate digestion and reduce discomfort.
  • Opt for light desserts like fruit or dark chocolate to avoid heavy digestive loads.
Every little effort can be rewarded with a healthy gut and overall fitness.

This article highlights various practices that can improve digestion and comfort after meals, emphasizing the importance of simple daily routines.
newTitle: 10 After-Dinner Rituals to Aid Digestion and Prevent Bloating
